alert.note: Alert for Knox (Indiana) Issued by the National Weather Service

info.headline: Flood Warning issued March 06 at 11:59AM EST until March 15 at 7:51AM EST by NWS Indianapolis
info.description: ...The Flood Warning continues for the following rivers in Indiana... Illinois... Wabash River. Wildcat Creek near Lafayette. .Minor flooding is ongoing along the Wabash, White, and East Fork White rivers and several tributaries across central and southern Indiana due to 1.5 to 3 inches of rainfall that fell Friday March 3rd. Flooding is ongoing along the full length of the Wabash River with the crest near Covington. Much of the White River is in flood from Spencer to Hazleton, with the crest near Elliston. Flooding along the East Fork White River is expected from Seymour to Williams, with the crest near Seymour. Flooding along many smaller tributaries that has not already ended will end by Tuesday. Flooding will continue through the middle to end of the week along portions of the Wabash, White and East Fork White, and into next week on lower portions of these rivers. ...FLOOD WARNING NOW IN EFFECT UNTIL WEDNESDAY, MARCH 15... * WHAT...Minor flooding is occurring and minor flooding is forecast. * WHERE...Wabash River at Vincennes. * WHEN...Until Wednesday, March 15. * IMPACTS...At 18.0 feet, Agricultural lands and some oil fields flood. Several township roads about 1.25 miles south of St. Francesville and River Road between Billett Road and Lincoln Memorial Bridge in Lawrence County are flooded. Extensive flooding of Kimmell Park at Vincennes. * ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 10:45 AM CST Monday /11:45 AM EST Monday/ the stage was 16.8 feet. - Recent Activity...The maximum river stage in the 24 hours ending at 10:45 AM CST Monday /11:45 AM EST Monday/ was 16.8 feet. - Forecast...The river is expected to rise to a crest of 18.9 feet Friday evening. It will then fall below flood stage Tuesday, March 14. - Flood stage is 16.0 feet. - http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood &&
info.instruction: Motorists should not attempt to drive around barricades or drive cars through flooded areas. Additional information is available at www.weather.gov/ind. This statement will be updated within the next 12 to 24 hours.
